concept.title: Handling accessibility in content and in processors
concept.shortdesc: Accssibility requirements vary based on how content is rendered. These requirements fall on both content owners and on the tools that render DITA content.

conbody.draft-comment: Initial draft-content, needs a lot of revision and need to add WCAG to the references
conbody.p: One of the best known standards for producing accessible content is the set of Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) from W3C. While content formats and content owners may always have unique or additional accessibility needs, the rules in WCAG provide a good reference point for describing how to create accessible content in DITA.

When considiring how to work with DITA, the guidelines fall into the following categories:
General content guidelines Many accessibility guidelines and best practices apply to all content, and are generally outside the scope of this specification.
For example, a guideline might recommend against multiple levels of nested unordered lists, because those lists are difficult to navigate with a screen reader. As a general content standard, DITA cannot prohibit such nesting. The best way to enforce such rules when they apply is through editorial gudelines, or by setting up an editor or content management system to prohibit its use.
As another example, recommendations to avoid flashing or flickering video content are outside the scope of this specification. DITA's video element is a general mechanism for including any video â€“ the content of that video is outside the scope of this specification.
Guidelines requiring specific markup Many other accessibility guidelines require use of specific DITA markup, and will be addressed in this section of the specification.
For example, a requirement that images specify alternate text requires use of the alt element within an image. However, a guideline that the alternate text be meaningful is not something that can be enforced by the markup, and falls into the first category.
Guidelines requiring enablement by DITA processors Some accessibility guidelines require processors to take advantage of specific DITA markup.
For example, by placing a header row in a table using thead or sthead, an author can define a header for every cell in the table body. If the relationship between table cell and header cell must be made specific in a rendered format like HTML, a processor can make those relationships explicit without any additional intervention by the author.
Processor requirements outside the scope of DITA markup Processors have many other accessibility concerns that are outside the scope of this specification.
For example, WCAG has a requirement for contrast ratios when rendering text content. That requirement is unrelated to the source content; instead, such requirements apply to the rendering tools such as CSS used to style DITA content in a browser.
As another example, a DITA processor might generate automated headings or text strings, such as a greater-than character (>) used between DITA phrases identified as a menu navigation. It is up to the processor to use correct markup for these cases, such as heading markup for any headings, and accessible text alternatives for character displays like the menu separator.
